Argentina was the first country where using crypto for payments was way easier than other methods:
- cash withdrawals from ATMs problematic with Swiss cards (!?)
- brought some USD but not enough
- Mercado Pago (local payments app) available via the @joinpeanut, but only if the merchant has QR codes (only businesses, not individuals)

How did I use it to pay random individuals then (taxi drivers, food vendors & kitesurfing instructor in a small countryside village)?

They use a local app @lemonapp_ar which accepts crypto payments over multiple networks (I used @arbitrum & @base, but more are available):
- they didn't really know how crypto works, I had to guide them through the steps (and did the classic 1 USD test)
- they didn't understand/care about the different networks available as long as eventually the app showed them an updated balance
- confirmation times were very annoying (a couple of minutes before the app showed payment as "Confirmed"), especially for small payments like lunch
- presumably the user can then convert directly to ARS?, but as non-Argentinian I couldn't actually try Lemon Cash

The only metric that seemed to matter was UX: how quickly can one person pay another. Two angles to UX:
- sharing a deposit address/"invoice" -> still a little clunky with 0xHEX (the native Lemon -> Lemon payments use an alias) & choosing between the different networks. This is new to non-crypto-natives
- confirmation speed

Security of the underlying chain not even questioned - users fully trust the app and assume that whatever is integrated into the app is safe - this is very nice for UX but can be potentially dangerous.
